bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to [John Clayton,] December 12, 1727

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to the colony's attorney general [John Clayton,] December 12, 1727, to welcome him and his son home from England, and to remind him of a law suit against Colonel Allerton's heir in which Clayton is acting for Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to [John Clayton,] December 12, 1727

opener.dateline:
[Corotoman, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Decr. the 12th: 1727
Mr. Attorney

div1.p:
having bin so long your Tennant and having
now an Opportunity to Town could not omitt paying you the
Compliment of welcome to Virginia and your Son that came
with you with wishes that you may have met with the Satisfact
ion of finding all things well here,

here is a Ship bound out in two or three days for
Leverpool if you have a desire to write to London. I can undertake the
Safety of your Letters the dangers of the Sea's Excepted I am with a great
deal of Sincerity
div1.closer:
Sir
Yor: most humble Servt:
I have a law Suit depending against
the heir of Colonel Allerton which I think
you are already Concernd for me in

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter letter book, 1727 May-1728 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.
The name of Carter's home, "Corotoman," the county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded draft

[2] Willoughby Allerton (1664-1724) was a prominent citizen of Westmoreland County where he was burgess, sheriff, and militia officer.
